title: Risky Medical Exams and Procedures
summary: The term 'risky' can refer to different factors: the potential for complications (like infection or bleeding), the amount of radiation exposure, or the consequences of an inaccurate result (a false-positive or false-negative). The exams listed here are generally safe, but have higher potential risks that must be weighed against their diagnostic benefits.

riskCategories.primaryRisk: Risk of Bleeding, Infection, or Perforation
riskCategories.description: These procedures involve inserting instruments, needles, or cameras into the body. While complications are rare, they can be serious.

procedures.name: Biopsies
procedures.description: A procedure to remove a small sample of tissue for testing, often to check for cancer.
potentialRisks: Damage to a nearby organ (e.g., collapsed lung during a lung biopsy)

procedures.name: Endoscopies
procedures.description: Using a flexible tube with a camera to look inside a part of the body.
potentialRisks: Rare risk of tearing or perforation of the organ wall

procedures.name: Cardiac Catheterization (Angiogram)
procedures.description: A thin, flexible tube is threaded through a blood vessel up to the heart to diagnose and treat heart conditions.
potentialRisks: Bleeding or bruising at the insertion site

procedures.name: Amniocentesis / Chorionic Villus Sampling (CVS)
procedures.description: Prenatal tests that involve taking a sample of amniotic fluid (amniocentesis) or placental tissue (CVS) to check for genetic abnormalities.

riskCategories.primaryRisk: Cumulative lifetime risk of cancer from ionizing radiation
riskCategories.description: These tests use ionizing radiation. The risk from a single scan is very low, but the risk increases with the number of scans a person has over their life.

procedures.name: Computed Tomography (CT or CAT) Scans
procedures.description: A series of X-ray images taken from different angles to create cross-sectional 'slices' of the body.
potentialRisks: Delivers a much higher dose of radiation than a standard X-ray
Harm to kidneys from contrast dye (in people with kidney problems)

procedures.name: Nuclear Medicine Scans
procedures.description: Involves swallowing, inhaling, or being injected with a small amount of a radioactive substance (a 'tracer') which is then tracked by a special camera.
potentialRisks: Radiation exposure from the radioactive tracer
Contribution to cumulative lifetime radiation dose

procedures.name: Fluoroscopy-Guided Procedures
procedures.description: A type of 'live' X-ray 'movie' used to guide procedures in real-time.
potentialRisks: Can involve high doses of radiation, especially for complex or long procedures

riskCategories.description: The risk here is not from the test itself, but from the consequences of a false result, which can lead to anxiety, unnecessary follow-up procedures, or delayed treatment.

procedures.name: False-Positives
procedures.description: The test indicates you have a condition that you do not actually have.
potentialRisks: Leads to unnecessary and riskier follow-up tests (e.g., an invasive biopsy)

procedures.name: False-Negatives
procedures.description: The test indicates you do not have a condition that you actually do have.
potentialRisks: Delay in diagnosis and treatment for a real, and potentially serious, disease
